title: The Ravens Went for It. And They Lost.
summary: The sixth-seeded Tennessee Titans shocked Baltimore 28-12, knocking off Lamar Jackson and the No. 1 seed. There wasn't just one reason the Baltimore Ravens were the NFL's best team this year. Their defense was really good, their Lamar Jackson-led offense was even better, and they made smarter decisions than any other team in the league.

title: The Houston Texans Were Up Big. Then Patrick Mahomes Happened.
summary: Down 24-0, the Chiefs quarterback engineered a thrilling comeback to take Kansas City to the AFC Championship. The Houston Texans were up 24-0, which was quite bad for the Chiefs. But Kansas City had Patrick Mahomes, which was even worse for the Texans.

title: U.S.-China Trade War Took Toll, but Minor One
summary: Economic data shows limited damage from tariffs, though it might take years to see full Impact. WASHINGTON-Farmers took a big hit. Importers of auto parts, furniture and machinery choked down punishing tariffs. Investment between the world's two largest economies dropped.

title: New U.S. Rule Limits When Two Companies Share Liability for Labor-Law Violations
summary: The Labor Department regulation provides long-sought clarity for franchised businesses and companies using contract staff. A new Labor Department rule will make it more difficult for workers to claim to have two employers simultaneously in cases where they are challenging wages and overtime, easing regulatory burdens for large franchised brands and companies using staffing firms.

title: Severe Weather Cuts Deadly Swath Across South
summary: Tornado in Alabama kills three people, while winter storm causes deaths in Texas. Residents across the South on Sunday were digging out from a barrage of heavy rains, wind storms and tornadoes that left several people dead and tens of thousands without power over the weekend.

title: Manufacturers Increase Perks to Get New Hires to Move
summary: Caterpillar, Raytheon among employers offering more relocation and other benefits to lure far-flung new hires. Manufacturers are paying relocation costs and bonuses to move new hires across the country at a time of record-low unemployment and intense competition for skilled workers.

title: 'Cancel Culture' Comes to Science
summary: A scholar with an agenda targets as 'dangerous' our conference on filtering out faulty research.. An unhappy side effect of the digital age is "cancel culture." Anyone with an attitude of moral superiority and a Twitter account can try to shut down an event where opinions he dislikes are likely to be spoken. For several years the National Association of Scholars has inveighed against this infantile form of protest, which undermines free expression of ideas and legitimate debate. Now the cancel caravan has arrived at our door.

title: U.S. Officials Defend Decision to Kill Iranian General
summary: Democrats and some Republicans accuse administration of exaggerating the rationale for the killing. WASHINGTON-White House officials on Sunday defended the U.S. killing of Iranian Maj. Gen. Qassem Soleimani, while acknowledging potential gaps in their assertion that four U.S. embassies had become imminent targets of Iranian attack.

title: A Prosecutorial Bridge Too Far
summary: A Supreme Court case that could criminalize common political mischief.. Political thuggery isn't a crime, but many prosecutors want to make it one. On Tuesday the Supreme Court will consider in U.S. v. Kelly whether public officials commit fraud when they misuse their authority or government funds for political purposes. Let's hope not because too many political differences are already criminalized.

title: Two Portents of Freedom
summary: Taiwan sends a message to Beijing and Iranians protest in the streets.. Democratic declinists claim authoritarians are on the march, but over the weekend the world saw people in two very different countries making significant statements against dictatorial rule.

title: A Bailout for Criminals
summary: New York's reform is freeing violent offenders who will harm again.. Label something "criminal-justice reform" these days and it's likely to be whisked into law in left-leaning states with little thought to the consequences. Witness the fiasco of New York's bail reform that took effect Jan. 1 and is already producing ill effects across the state.

title: 'If We Stayed Outside We Would Have Died': Australia's Fires Devour Farms and Forests
summary: Resume Subscription. TUMBARUMBA, Australia-Neil Hamilton spent New Year's Eve shooting his sheep in the head.

title: Exxon Considers Sale of Oil Assets in Equatorial Guinea
summary: African nation looks to companies from Russia, elsewhere as potential successors to U.S. firm. ABU DHABI- Exxon Mobil Corp. is in talks to sell its oil assets in Equatorial Guinea, the country's oil minister said, and might be replaced there by a Russian company-among other options-as U.S. companies retreat to shale projects and Moscow strengthens its foothold in African resources.

title: Soleimani's Latin America Terror
summary: President Trump's decision to kill him is good news for the Western Hemisphere.. The death of Iranian Maj. Gen. Qasem Soleimani is a blow to the theocracy's efforts to assert its power across the Middle East. By taking out Soleimani, President Trump also did Latin America a big favor.

title: Your DNA Could Catch a Criminal
summary: Genetic databases are solving murders and rapes. Privacy scolds should pipe down.. In December, Michigan police arrested Robert Brian Thomas as a suspect in two cases of sexual battery-committed in Florida in 1998. These were the latest of hundreds of cold cases investigated since the Federal Bureau of Investigation's April 2018 arrest of Joseph James DeAngelo, the alleged Golden State Killer. There are still hundreds of thousands of untested rape kits nationwide, but now technology may make it almost impossible to get away with this crime. Privacy concerns are an obstacle in solving cold cases-but not an insurmountable one.

title: The Man on the Street Has Died
summary: Asking the public's view is out; reporting 'expert' tweets is in.. When I was a rookie at ABC News decades ago, our coverage of big stories-from war to impeachment to the World Series-always included plenty of "man on the street," or MOS. As soon as important news broke, a pack of reporters from TV, radio and print dashed to New York's iconic crossroads, Times Square or Grand Central Terminal, to learn what "average" folks were thinking.

title: 'Fully Grown' Review: Pumping the Brakes
summary: The rate of economic growth has slowed over the past two decades. Structural changes in the labor force could be to blame.. America's economic growth appears to have sputtered in the 21st century. While America's real gross domestic product grew at a blistering rate of 4.2% a year between 1950 and 1970, real GDP growth has increased by only 2% annually since 2000. A sense of decline infects our national mood.

title: Oman's Sultan Was a Valuable Friend to America
summary: Qaboos helped in the Iran hostage crisis and the Gulf War and was a voice for moderation in the region.. Few Americans have heard of Qaboos bin Said al-Said, the sultan of Oman. But when he died Friday at 79, the U.S. lost an invaluable interlocutor. In nearly 50 years on the throne, Qaboos time and again helped presidents navigate delicate diplomatic and military challenges.

title: Paris Pension Protests Are Petering Out
summary: Macron is enduring the longest transportation strike in French history.. Paris

title: Pelosi Defends Delay in Sending Impeachment Articles
summary: The House speaker says timing is unclear and suggests Bolton could be subpoenaed. House Speaker Nancy Pelosi on Sunday defended her delay in sending articles of impeachment to the Senate, which is expected this week and will set the stage for a historic trial of President Trump.

title: Making Labor Rules Rational Again
summary: A new regulation will undo Obama's aggressive 'joint employer' definition.. Deregulation has been the unsung economic success story of the Trump administration. Today the Labor Department adds its "joint employer" rule to the long list of deregulatory wins. When joint employment exists, two separate companies are responsible for ensuring that workers receive the federally mandated minimum wage and overtime pay. Two companies are responsible for ensuring the proper records are kept. And two companies can be taken to court if it's alleged that those responsibilities have not been met.

title: Behind Maduro's Latest Power Play: Reviving Venezuela's Collapsed Oil Industry
summary: Government wants control of the National Assembly so it can bring in foreign investors to revive crude production. CARACAS, Venezuela-A recent tussle between Maduro loyalists and the U.S.-backed opposition for control of Venezuela's National Assembly descended into a melee of competing claims that left neither side with clear authority over the assembly.

title: Awards Bump Powers '1917' to Box-Office Gains
summary: World War I action-drama unseats latest Star Wars movie from No. 1 spot. After nabbing best-picture honors at last weekend's Golden Globes awards, World War I action-drama "1917" opened strong enough to dethrone the latest Star Wars movie, which had ruled atop the box office for three consecutive weeks.

title: Economy Week Ahead: U.S. Retail Sales, Consumer Price Index, Federal Budget
summary: U.S. Commerce Department to release retail-sales data Thursday. In the week ahead, the U.S. Treasury Department publishes fresh data on government budget deficits, the Labor Department releases figures on inflation and the Commerce Department publishes data on retail sales in December. China also releases data on economic output.

title: Fragile Cease-Fire Begins in Libya
summary: The Tripoli government accused a renegade commander's forces of violating the truce just hours after it became effective. A fragile cease-fire began in Libya on Sunday after months in which foreign military intervention intensified a civil war that has raged on Europe's doorstep.

title: Aramco Adds to Record IPO
summary: The oil giant netted an additional $3.8 billion from its IPO, now worth $29.4 billion. DUBAI-Saudi Aramco said it netted an additional $3.8 billion from its record initial public offering as it sold more shares to meet investor demand, boosting Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman's war chest to reshape the country's oil-dependent economy.

title: Pete Buttigieg, a Veteran of Afghanistan War
summary: I respect that Pete Buttigieg chose to put himself in harm's way rather than exercising one of the various artful dodges employed by other leading politicians.. Regarding Greg Kelly and Katie Horgan's "Buttigieg's War and 'The Shortest Way Home'" (op-ed, Jan. 7): Mayor Pete was a stellar graduate of Harvard University; there is no organization that would not gladly have welcomed him into its ranks. The Navy was lucky to have such an obviously qualified candidate. Mayor Pete is multilingual in eight languages, including Arabic.

title: Mutant McCarthyism Reappears on Campus
summary: Many college campuses represent an exact, ideological mirror image of the McCarthy era.. The situation of UCLA law professor Stephen Bainbridge represents an extremely frightening situation for our entire country ("Notable & Quotable: 'Diversity and Inclusion,'" Jan. 3). He cites the ratio of liberal to conservative faculty members as 166 to 6 at Cornell, 151 to 17 at Stanford, 141 to 9 at UCLA, and 116 to 5 at Colorado. He also states the stunning fact that at 92.67% of all UCLA Law employees' political contributions went to Democrats and affiliated groups, and that few Republican donors are hired.

title: The New California Rules Burden Nonprofits
summary: Nonprofit religious institutions are among the many organizations besides Uber Technologies Inc., Lyft Inc. and truckers that are affected by California's rushed legislation.. Nonprofit religious institutions are among the many organizations besides Uber Technologies Inc., Lyft Inc. and truckers that are affected by California's rushed legislation ("New Rules Reshape Business in California," U.S. News, Jan. 2). We've consulted two attorneys and talked to a member of the assembly team that wrote the legislation, and there is still a gray area about when a person must become an employee.

title: Currency Boards Have a Good Record and Work Well
summary: A key selling point of currency boards is that they do away with discretion and promote stability and growth.. In his letter ("Currency Board for Africa Has Two Key Limitations," Jan. 6) responding to my "Farewell to the CFA Franc" (op-ed, Dec. 31), George Ayittey asserts that leaders in the region would never go for a currency board because it "would require member states to surrender control of monetary policy." In fact, discretionary monetary policy, as practiced in Africa and other developing regions, has proven to be a great destabilizer that has hindered growth and development. A key selling point of currency boards is that they do away with discretion and promote stability and growth. I know from my experience in introducing currency boards in the postcommunist countries of Estonia, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Bulgaria and Lithuania that leaders can easily discern the dangers of discretionary monetary policy.

title: 'Woke' Attack on Bloomberg Police Policies Is Irrational
summary: Mr. Bloomberg's policies saves black lives and contribute to making minority neighborhood's safer but these policies are presumed to turn off members of the black community and hurt his candidacy. This doesn't make any sense.. William McGurn cites Michael Bloomberg's persuasive argument that his policies as mayor of New York saved lives, many lives, and more than 90% of them likely to have been black or Hispanic ("Let Bloomberg Be Bloomberg," Main Street, Jan. 7). Yet Mr. Bloomberg felt obliged to apologize for these policies because "the Democratic Party simply won't nominate for president anyone who can't turn out black voters." This is a curious pair of statements. Mr. Bloomberg's policies saves black lives and contribute to making minority neighborhood's safer but these policies are presumed to turn off members of the black community and hurt his candidacy. This doesn't make any sense. This is a communications challenge that Mr. Bloomberg appears capable of handling effectively. The more likely explanation is that the apology tour was required to win the support of the "woke" wing of the Democratic Party, most of whom have little experience dealing with the daily realities of high-crime neighborhoods. They do, however, vote in primaries.

title: Malta's Ruling Party Chooses New Prime Minister Amid Murder Probe
summary: Election of lawyer Robert Abela comes amid probe of whether government mishandled inquiry into journalist's 2017 murder. A lawmaker with close ties to Maltese Prime Minister Joseph Muscat is replacing the embattled politician, who stepped down Sunday amid a probe into whether the government mishandled the investigation into the 2017 murder of a journalist.

title: It's Winter, and Cherry Blossoms Are Pink in Central Park
summary: Resume Subscription. Some New Yorkers did a double-take as cherry blossoms flowered in Central Park over the past few days, thanks to unusually mild weather.

title: Beijing Dismisses Taiwan Voters' Rebuke Over Its Claims to Island
summary: Taiwanese brace for more mainland pressure after rejecting the kind of coercion that has spurred Hong Kong's resistance. TAIPEI-An emphatic rebuke from Taiwanese voters against China's authoritarian influence drew disdain in Beijing, prompting some in Taiwan to brace for greater coercive measures from the Communist Party.

title: Wirecard Chairman Steps Down From Embattled Payments Giant
summary: Wulf Matthias, who resisted calls for an independent audit, resigned suddenly and will be succeeded by Thomas Eichelmann. Wirecard AG's chairman, who resisted calls for an independent audit of the under-fire German payments group, quit his role, effective immediately-a move the company said was aimed at improving its corporate governance.

title: Geneticists Call on Myriad to Share Proprietary Data to Aid Gene Tests
summary: They want to help the scientific community better assess the disease-causing risk of mutations. A leading medical society is calling on Myriad Genetics Inc. and other lab companies to share proprietary data from their genetic testing in a public database, to help the scientific community better assess the disease-causing risk of mutations.

title: Joe Burrow, Trevor Lawrence Duel for College Football's Championship
summary: The final between LSU and Clemson features the best quarterback match-up in the sport's recent history. NEW ORLEANS-No matter what happens in Monday night's college-football title game, Louisiana State quarterback Joe Burrow will likely follow his historic 2019 campaign by being selected first in the 2020 NFL draft. The same likely goes for Clemson quarterback Trevor Lawrence, though his draft day will not come until at least 2021.

title: Florida Considers Panic Alarms for Schools to Respond to Shootings
summary: Some states mandate systems that instantly transmit data to 911 dispatchers, law enforcement. A bill to require panic alarms in Florida public schools is expected to be considered in the state legislative session getting under way this week, as lawmakers continue to grapple with the deadly Parkland school shooting two years ago.

title: New NYPD Counterterrorism Chief Is First Woman to Lead Bureau
summary: Martine Materasso, a rising star in the department, stepped into the critical job at a particularly busy moment for terrorism in the region. As a little girl, New York Police Department Chief of Counterterrorism Martine Materasso attended Christmas parties at the Manhattan precinct where her father was commanding officer.

title: New Hampshire Voters Weigh Their Options as Democratic Primary Nears
summary: Elizabeth Warren is facing stiff competition in Granite State, where no clear front-runner has emerged. DOVER, N.H.-Benjamin Bolger, an educational consultant from Hanover, N.H., left Elizabeth Warren's rally no more certain about his vote than when he arrived.

title: High Drug Prices? Pharma Startup Thinks It Has the Right Medicine
summary: EQRx plans 10 drugs in the next decade with prices as low as one-third to one-fifth of their rivals. A startup pharmaceuticals company wants to capitalize on the backlash against high drug prices by developing slightly different versions of expensive brand-name drugs and selling them at a significantly lower price than competitors.

title: Iran's Plane Shootdown Sparks Anger at Home
summary: Security forces in Tehran fired tear gas to disperse hundreds of people who took to the streets in protest against the military. Iran's admission that its armed forces shot down a Ukrainian passenger airliner appeared intended to salvage its credibility at a time of heightened international tension and domestic unrest. Instead, it triggered quick anger from Iranians aimed at the country's leadership.

title: Why Podcast Fans Are Crazy About 'Blood Ties'
summary: A ripped-from-the-headlines tale tops the charts amid a new wave of fictional podcasts taking their cues from true crime. The popular new podcast "Blood Ties" tells the story of siblings Eleonore and Michael Richland, who are left to pick up the pieces after their parents' private plane vanishes en route to a family Christmas vacation in the Caribbean.

title: Bristol's Merger With Celgene Is Already Paying Dividends, CEO Says
summary: New drugs are timely as the combined company faces looming patent expirations and intensified competition in cancer therapies. Bristol-Myers Squibb Co. , fresh off completing one of the largest drug-industry mergers ever, is counting on the acquisition to pay off quickly with new products and ease Wall Street concerns.

title: Bets on Global-Growth Rebound Power Stock Gains
summary: Rosy outlook for global growth, following positive developments from trade talks and central banks, is fueling bets that stock gains can continue. Investors enter the heart of fourth-quarter earnings season optimistic that the world economy will pick up steam in 2020, a turnaround from last year that some hope can push stocks to fresh highs.

title: Bank Stocks Had a Bonanza in 2019. Earnings Will Be More Blah.
summary: Lower rates were a mixed bag for big banks; here's what to watch for in banks' quarterly results. Falling interest rates were a mixed bag for big U.S. banks last year. That should be evident when they report fourth-quarter earnings this week.

title: He's a Boss in the Kitchen and a Strongman on the Side
summary: A Boston chef uses strength training to stay fit on the job and keep his ADHD symptoms in check. To successfully run four restaurants and still work by the stove most nights, Chris Coombs needs to stay hyper-focused. For the 35-year-old Boston chef-restaurateur, that means staying disciplined about diet and exercise.

title: The Virtuous Midlife Crisis
summary: Forget the sports car and new trophy spouse. For Generation X, it's yoga, meditation retreats and keto diets.. Tom Finn, a 57-year-old baby boomer, celebrated his 50th birthday with a raucous trip to Las Vegas: He and his friends went ziplining, nightclubbing and played blackjack at swim-up tables in a pool at Caesars Palace. "I was a frat boy wanting to relive my college youth," he says.
